reviews.comment_teaching:
For the 4 professor, Danny and King Chow is teaching the best, both of them their tone are clear, but they talk really fast, so students will easily miss the important concept. If you cannot follow, I strongly advise you to ask them after class.

For Hung, Siu Chun. the powerpoint a dull, explanation is not doing well due to his tone, but he will give you a detailed walk through of every step of the analysis.

Finally for Xue Hong. She is probably the worse professor I have ever met, there is no doubt that her power point is detailed. However, the power point is in fact power paragraph, Moreover, she skip all the pictures in the powerpoint and direct read aloud the powerpoint's content.

reviews.author: diudiu
reviews.title: Challenging yet rewarding
reviews.comment_content:
About everything you need to learn about genetics, from the basic mendelian rules (now with 1000% more crossing over) to recombinant DNA tech to population genetics and evolution.

The first half, taught by Eugene, is mostly mechanical and largely overlaps with what used to be covered in HKALE except for certain more advanced tests/techniques. (40% of grade)
The second half is jointly taught by King Chow, CY Leung (:P) and Xue Hong (each 20%)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Eugene Hung
I kind of feel sorry for him, being handed one of the most boring/mechanical parts of the course. He teaches with heart and  "nice" is an understatement for him; however, he is not helped by his slow and accented speech.

Anyway, this is the part where you should grab as much points as possible to secure a good grade as everyone does well here.

King Chow
Attending a lecture by Prof Chow is like watching an episode of Sherlock; it is an exhilarating ride that's truly thrilling and enthralling - but that is if you could understand the convoluted plot. For others who, unfortunately, could not decipher his lectures, it is the most confusing thing in the world.

Unfortunately, the "others" include the majority of the class: the average score for his section is 6.20/20, which KC already considers "quite high" (last year it's 3.78/20)

Danny Leung
Quite the eloquent speaker. Native accent, appropriate speed and clear delivery in a somewhat comfortable traditional style of teaching. Uses lively examples to demonstrate his concepts.

His lectures were kind of straight forward and not too difficult, so most students wouldn't encounter problems here.

Xue Hong
Absolute waste of time. Horrendous accent and sluggish teaching pace, not to mention the fact that she reads directly from her powerpoint slides. I finished all her lectures and tutorials (I skipped them) in maybe 3 or 4 hours.
reviews.comment_grading:
Nominally absolute grading. In reality, Eugene just sets the grade thresholds according to the distribution so it's not really that different from grading on a pro-rata basis/拉curve.
Overall grading (%):
A+ (>= 80), A (75-79.99), A- (70-74.99)
B+ (65-69.99), B (59-64.99), B- (53-58.99)
C+ (47-52.99), C (41-46.99), C- (35-40.99)
D (25-34.99), F (< 25)
Mean = 53.13; SD = 16.8
I got lucky and snatched an A+ with 80.13% (yay).
reviews.comment_workload:
Some people call genetics a "killer course" as its style differs from traditional life science courses quite a lot (well at least for KC's part and arguably Eugene's) as there wasn't much rote memorisation and require a great deal of logical deductions and reasoning, as well as a clear grasp of the underlying concepts. Therefore, one is expected to devote more effort and time towards this course.

There are weekly assignments which would be discussed during a tutorial session. They are not graded though, so you're not obliged to work on them. However, I would strongly recommend everyone to at least finish Eugene's and KC's assignments, the former being essential to familiarise yourself with the calculations (it gets mechanical as you work on more problems); and the latter being a fun thought exercise.

reviews.author: royalmilktea
reviews.comment_content: See attachment :D
reviews.comment_teaching:
This course is taught by 4 professors this year
Eugene taught the first month or so, then King Chow until midterm, and then Danny and Hannah after midterm.

Eugene
He's a pretty clear in teaching the concepts, and really makes sure you understand (if he doesn't get good responses he'll literally put together another powerpoint to reexplain the problem the next lecture)
He repeats the key concepts 3 times though, so it's okay to zone out a bit in class
What I don't like is he doesn't do enough practice questions with us in class, so I don't know how to do like half of the tutorial questions
If he taught faster and did a bit more practice with us that would be great.

King Chow
KC doesn't really teach according to his powerpoint
His classes are more discussion sessions on key concepts and then 5 minutes later he'll be like, "okay so we covered this, this, and this" -skips a bunch of slides-
It's okay though, because his exam isn't according to his powerpoint anyway. Just treat his powerpoint as some key concepts (which he will stress over and over again in class) + other interesting information you may want to know (which he will skip in class)
His exam questions are more experimental design and big picture stuff, and the tutorial questions should give you a good idea what they will be like.
Oh, and don't sit in the front if you're scared of being asked questions; he points to people sometimes.
But if you're into scientific discussions, KC's classes will be very interesting and fun.

Danny
A new professor in LIFS (and a very cute one indeed)
I have a feeling he's going the KC route, but he's less intimidating I guess?
He teaches clearly but very quickly, perhaps even faster than KC (because he's covering things on the powerpoint, unlike KC's discussion style)
His exam is very much based on the powerpoint, but there is one long question that was like an experimental design problem (like what KC would give, really)
So if you have no problems with KC's style you'll probably enjoy Danny just as much (or even a bit more)
Oh, and study the tutorial questions (at least memorize the answers). Some of the MCs may appear in the final ;)

Hannah
She basically reads off her very word-full powerpoint, and you may feel slightly... drowsy during class. Be sure to read the textbook chapters she posts too though, because they will appear in the exam.
I'm not a fan of her posting tutorial questions like 3 hours before the tutorial, because neither we nor the tutor have enough time to look at them, so we're all just thinking about the questions for the first time in class. As a result, our tutor's teaching quality greatly dropped during those two classes.
She taught 2 chapters this year, Chapter 19 and 23 (see attached course outline for details)
The exam questions for chapter 23 were okay, if you understand the powerpoint and the textbook you should be able to get them right (they're pretty much just calculations and basic concepts on population genetics)
However, the questions on chapter 19 (genomics) were... I have no idea where they came from. They were very paper/research-based, asking you to make inferences from some random conclusion. I wasn't even sure I was in the right exam room when I did them.
Just give it up to luck. Chances are, others will do just as poorly.
reviews.comment_grading:
I don't know if it's because people keep on saying it's a killer course (so I expected really low grades)
but I got better than expected based on comparison with the mean and SD...
reviews.comment_workload:

You can choose to not do it and just learn from your tutor if you're really out of time
Though you'll probably learn more if you did it once beforehand so you can discuss your own answers during the tutorial

reviews.author: thatperson
reviews.title: Tedious but Challenging
reviews.comment_content: This is one of the most difficult LIFS course I've ever taken so far. There were a lot of content to understand and many were quite new to me. Be prepared to spend most of your revision time on this since this is a 4 credit course and has a heavy weighting on your GPA.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I found King Chow and Danny's part quite intriguing and found them enjoyable. They were able to engage and address any questions by the students but I wish they went a bit slower. There were tons of info to take in in a short period of time.
For Prof Xue and Prof Hung, they were typical professor who goes through PPT without much engagement with students. However, they are very passionate to help with any problems regarding to the course.
reviews.comment_grading:
Please refer to other reviews from Fall 2016-2017. There are grading ranges based on your numerical scores.

I got below mean during midterm but above mean in finals, and I got B range. Better than expected
reviews.comment_workload: There are tons of reading to do. You will lag behind a lot if you are lazy. There are many tutorial questions and it is best if you try them. King Chow tutorial questions are most useful when you are trying to grasp his method of thinking.

reviews.author: TimothyGrass
reviews.title: Practice makes perfect
reviews.comment_content:
Hung's part is mainly calculation
Including:
1. Law of Segragation & Pedigree Analysis
2. Sex Linkage
3. Law of Independent Assortment
4. Extensions of Mendelian Genetics
5. Quantitative Traits
6. Population Genetics
7. Genetic Linkage, Crossing Over & Genetic Mapping

Danny's part is mainly experiment methods and tools, including:
1. Application of Recombinant DNA Technology & Forward Genetics

reviews.comment_teaching:
Hung's part is comparatively boring and tedious. He likes to repeat steps with a very detail way which some may think it overdetailed. But overall it is straight forward and clear. A lot of questions are provided for practices and examination questions are pretty much based on the format.

Danny has a very intersting teaching but the contents are comparatively harder. Less questions are provided for practice.
reviews.comment_grading:
Both very straight forward rating system.
Hung's part has a examination is very similar to mathametics, all of them are long questions and some require explaination.
Danny's part includes MC and long questions. MC in appropriate difficulty and long questions are mainly laboratory situation and experiment based. Hard, but very interesting questions.
reviews.comment_workload:
No work load basically.
Questions behind each chapter are provided in Hung's part so we can do practice with it. Checking once a week in the tutorial.
Danny provides questions for each chapter. Also checking each week in the tutorial.
Both of them provides zoom tutorial. No attendence will be marked so you can skip if you want, although I suggest attending them via zoom, it helps a lot.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Eugene speaks very slowly. He tries his best to explain concepts and answer questions. I'd say try to understand what he says the first time he says it because after his first explanation it'll only get more complicated and messy. If you really don't understand the first time, try asking him after the lecture, he explains it better at that time. Try also your best to attend his tutorials, the questions he uses and methods he shows are very useful in the exams.

Danny speaks wayyy too fluently. It's almost an enjoyment to attend his class. However, he's really good at what he teaches so he may go a bit too fast while explaining some critical concepts. Try asking him questions during the lecture because students often as the same questions and he would low key get annoyed by it. His tutorials are very useful as well because similar questions appear in the exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
Kinda harsh but not unrealistic. If you volunteered in Eugene's tutorials you will get extra points, so make sure you do so if you wanna have a better grade.

No one scored higher than 90% in Danny's part this semester so you don't have to score as high to get in A range (I only got B+ though). The means for three parts (Eugene's mid term, Eugene's final and Danny's final) are 27.11/50, 6.63/10 and 22.22/40 respectively.

A+: >=86, A: 80-85.75, A-: 74-79.75
B+: 68-73.75, B: 62-67.75, B-: 56-61.75
C+: 50-55.75. C: 44-49.75, C-: 38-43.75
D: 26-37.75
reviews.comment_workload:
I wouldn't say the workload is bad because it's just a standard LIFS course: 50% mid term 50% final. And to be honest there isn't particularly much to memorise. As long as you do enough exercises (provided by Eugene), you will do well in his part.

As for Danny's part, do memorise the way he wants you to formulate answers. I regret not spending enough time studying his questions before the finals and that's why I couldn't score better.

reviews.author: ggg_
reviews.comment_content:
A standard genetics course.
1. Law of segregation and pedigree analysis
2. Sex Linkage
3. Law of Independent Assortment
4. Extensions of Mendelian Genetics
5. Quantitative traits
6. Population genetics
7. Genetic linkage, crossing over and genetic mapping
8. Genetic mapping in humans
----------------midterm (Eugene HUNG)-----------
9. Recombinant DNA technology
10. Forward genetics
11. Reverse genetics
12. Genomics
13. Epigenetics
----------------final (Danny LEUNG)----------------

It seems that the part covered by Eugene are barely useful in research nowadays. However, it is still required to give you a basic and good understanding of classic genetics. Some statistics and calculations are involved. The calculations are not difficult, but you need to understand the reason and principle behind that. Danny's parts are research hotspots and I think epigenetics is really interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Eugene:
I can tell he is a kind teacher, but he talks reaaaally slowly and make me hard to concentrate and wanna sleep. There are no rises and falls in his tone and the words are interrupted by "emm" from time to time. His classes are not very efficient for me. But his slides are organized. He replies to discussions and emails patiently and in detail. However, if you ask him questions in person, sometimes he cannot answer you immediately. He make notes on the answers of tutorial exercises as some answers on the original textbook may be wrong. (Make sure you are using the annotated version)
Danny:
His English is good and sound like native speaker. He teaches passionately and you can tell he has expertise in this field. His tones and pace keep me awake much better than Eugene's. He stop from time to time to ask if we have any questions. He encourages students to raise their questions in class so that other students with similar doubts may listen as well, which is efficient. He don't give answers of tutorial questions and won't say it out if no one interact with him and propose their solutions, which is a bit awkward.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think the grading is fair. It seems to be neither absolute grading or curve grading but a combination. The professors will decide the cutoff for each subgrade based on the performance of the students.

Midterm: 50% Final: 50%
Eugene's part: 60% Danny's part: 40%
(It is because Eugene taught too slow and part of the contents that should be tested in the midterm were moved to the final)

Midterm:
Mean: 27.11  Median: 26.88 High: 49.5   Low: 3
Upper Quartile: 35.13 Lower Quartile: 18.31

reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is ok for a 4 credit course. If you attend lectures and jot down notes, do the tutorial exercise and make sure you understand them, you are likely to get good grades in the exam. However, I did spend much time understanding Danny's part. It is more interesting than the previous parts and at the same time more difficult.(in my opinion)
The midterm exam is more comprehensive than the exercises provided (only 7 questions for 3 hrs), so you need to have a good understanding of the concepts and apply them under different settings. The final exam composed of around 30 MCs, 10 or so short questions and a few long questions. The questions really resembles the tutoral exercises provided by Danny, so make good use of them if you want to get good grades.

Eugene Hung is a friendly instructor. You can feel that he tried his best to explain the content. He is willing to answer students' questions. I think better skip his lecture and wait for the recording. Tune the speed to 1.25x/1.5x will be better to listen.

Danny Leung is also a nice professor. He always engage the class to involve in his lecture and ask if anything students' not understood. Most importantly, his English is very good that you feel comfortable listening to him.

reviews.author: bich forever
reviews.title: Interesting course which trains your logic
reviews.comment_content:
The parts from Eugene and King Chow  teaches a lot stuff regarding genetics which you will need to understand in order to work on the questions in the exams. You can do well either by working really really hard, or understand the stuff thoroughly.
Hannah's part mostly does not require any understanding if you simply aim at doing well in the exam. Just memorize the lecture material will be good enough.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Eugene teaches very carefully but slowly and he is a super nice guy. Contents are relatively simple and through working on the question sets you can do well in the exam easily.

King Chow teaches very well but the materials is a bit difficult which requires you to understand his stuff. Try to make sure you really understand the reasoning behind. No use to memorize stuff.

Hannah's part is the worst in the course to me. Bad English accent, just like reading words in the ppt. Just memorize for the exam.

Tutorial classes are very important. Make sure you really try your best to work on the question set before attending. No use if you simply go into the classroom without working on the questions. Make sure you know the steps clearly.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
Heavily depends on how well you would like to do.

If you really understand the knowledge, the workload is quite light indeed.

reviews.author: Gyudaeng
reviews.title: Two good, two bad
reviews.comment_content:
Eugene: Solve 100 textbook and tutorial questions, then you will ace the mid-term exam.

King: Don't focus on the slide information.

Danny: Study his slides and concentrate on everything he says. They directly come up in the finals.

Hannah: Half of the questions on the finals paper are not explained at all in her slides.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Eugene's teaching style might be monotonous. However, when you listen to him carefully, you will find yourself understanding the material. Very fond of him.

King is passionate in his teaching. Compared to the amount he talks however, there are not many concepts that you can understand or remember.

I very much like Danny's teaching style. One of the best. He is the master of explanation. His tone and pronunciation are perfect. He makes sure students understand by explaining again and inviting questions.

Hannah. First time I fell asleep.

70% and I got A-.

Mid-term is a good chance to boost up the grade.

Workload is appropriate.

It depends on how much you are willing to spend time solving questions (for Eugene's part)

Only one mid-term and final. Nice and pleasant.

reviews.author: AChan
reviews.title: LIFS3140
reviews.comment_teaching:
1. King Chow: only taught for the mid-term part. As the most famous professor in Life science, you probably have heard about him. He is a good teacher, only if you are smart enough to follow his mind. He speaks at normal speed, but you will feel headache after every class. reviews.comment_content:
The first half semester is all about PROBABILITY or I'll say is all about maths mix with some genetics things. You really have to follow the tutorial and do exercises if you do not want to get lost.
• Basic Mendelian genetics
• Extension of Mendelian genetics

• Application of recombinant DNA
technology in forward & reverse genetics

reviews.comment_teaching:
You DONNOT want to skip the TUTORIAL!! I skip all which make me feel lost.
The First half of the lecture can be attend as the concept is hard. But I think the instructor explanation is not good. Sometimes, he will invite student to explain the concept. I think the student is better than him.

You can just skip the second half lecture but not the tutorial of the entire semester!
reviews.comment_grading:
50% MID-TERM
50% FINAL

Both mid-term and final is not MC. IT IS ALL LONG QUESTION!!
Especially the mid-term is a maths exam literally. It is CLOSE BOOK exam. But luckily, past paper and exercises will be provided. You really need to do exercise!
